subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] On PALM
msgSnippet: Regarding Ado+Roar , I agree with the solution of using ligature/separated letters to indicate unstressed/stressed distinctions. I believe you suggested this
messageBody:
Regarding 'Ado+Roar', I agree with the solution of using
ligature/separated letters to indicate unstressed/stressed
distinctions. I believe you suggested this yourself earlier, Paul.
Another stylistic choice could be to switch to the alternate
letter-form 'Up' in words such as 'arrest'.

I've been meaning to bring up the way that the SQUARE, NEAR, and CURE
sets are handled in your News program. A quick look in the dictionary
highlights the problem:

SQUARE S K W EH1 R
NEAR N IH1 R
CURE K Y UH1 R

Earlier John linked the choices we make for these sets together:

Set Choice 1 Choice 2
SQUARE Et + Roe Eight + Roe
NEAR It + Roe Eat + Roe
CURE Foot + Roe Ooze + Roe

Later he came up with a convincing argument for Choice 2. I think your
program should look for R following these vowels and modify them as
needed. I haven't looked yet to see how many words would be converted
incorrectly by such a simple rule, but if it turns out to be a large
number, then I guess we're stuck with Choice 1.

Of course, if we merge 'Foot' and 'Ooze' then the last one goes away.
I'd be fine with that. But I'm still contemplating the larger change
that Anthony has proposed...

Ted


On Nov 20, 2007 2:14 PM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> John Cowan wrote:
> >
> >
> > The PALM lexical set is pretty small, I should probably explain.
> > It consists of words written "al" where the "l" is no longer
> > pronounced, as in "palm" itself; foreign words where the original
> > vowel is preserved, like "drama" and "pasta" (though some speakers put
> > these in TRAP instead); and the special word "father", which should
> > have gone into FACE like other words with original long "a" if all
> > had gone as expected (and is so pronounced in broad Yorkshire), but
> > was reshaped, probably because it is a papa-mama word, and they never
> > follow the usual rules. (There's a nice writeup on such words at
> > http://www.sussex.ac.uk/linguistics/documents/where_do_mama2.pdf
> > <http://www.sussex.ac.uk/linguistics/documents/where_do_mama2.pdf> .)
> >
> > Also, don't forget that even people who merge THOUGHT and PALM (and
> > therefore have CLOTH = THOUGHT = PALM) don't merge NORTH/FORCE and START.
> >
>
> I assume you are lumping together NORTH/FORCE here because only a small
> group of speakers distinguishes between the two sets. (I do, but the
> distinction is pretty weak even for me.)
>
> The problem with vowels before Roar should be handled separately,
> perhaps. I think some of the vowel + r sequences should have their own
> set of letters or even a special ligature. Fore example, the combination
> Ado + Roar serves for the NURSE set, but sometimes this sequence can be
> confusing. For example, QS spells the word "arrest" Ado-Roar-Ed-Sis-Tut.
> The first three vowels can be confusing, since a reader doesn't know if
> Ado goes with Roar to give the same sound in NURSE, or, if it stands
> alone so that Roar goes with Ed. Perhaps more experience readers don't
> have this problem. But if we have a ligature for Ado + Roar that always
> equals the sound in NURSE, we can avoid this confusion. So arrest would
> be spelled the same way, to keep the Ado separate, but the word "nurse"
> itself would be spelled Nun Ligatutre-of-Ado-Roar, Sis.
>
> Anyway, I'm just trying to point out that the vowel before Roar
> situation needs to be discussed a bit more. I see words appearing in the
> news that still give me difficulty. Besides the example above, I come
> across the Ed Roar combination for words in which I would use Age-Roar.
> It takes me a while to figure out such words.
>
> Paul
>
